dataset.title: Soil moisture and temperature along an elevation gradient at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, 2010 - present.

abstract.para: Soil temperature and soil moisture have been measured at multiple locations at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest (HBEF), as part of a study of the relationships between snow depth, soil freezing and nutrient cycling (http://www.ecostudies.org/people_sci_groffman_snow_summary.html).Â In October 2010, we established 6, 20 x 20-m plots (intensive plots) and 14 10 x 10-m plots (extensive plots) along an elevation gradient, with eight of the plots on north-facing slopes and twelve on south-facing slopes. Soil temperature and soil moisture were measured at hourly intervals on these plots beginning in November 2010. Six locations were discontinued in September 2012 (E04, E05, E06, E11-B, E13, and E14).

These data were gathered as part of the Hubbard Brook Ecosystem Study (HBES). The HBES is a collaborative effort at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, which is operated and maintained by the USDA Forest Service, Northern Research Station.

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study.

While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

section.title: LOCATION DESCRIPTION
section.para: Soil temperature and soil moisture have been measured at multiple locations at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest (HBEF), as part of a study of the relationships between snow depth, soil freezing and nutrient cycling (http://www.ecostudies.org/people_sci_groffman_snow_summary.html). In October 2010, we established 6 20 x 20-m plots (intensive plots) and 14 10 x 10-m plots (extensive plots) along an elevation gradient, with eight of the plots on north-facing slopes and twelve on south-facing slopes. Soil temperature and soil moisture were measured at hourly intervals on these plots beginning in November 2010. Six locations were discontinued in September 2012 (E04, E05, E06, E11-B, E13, and E14).

section.title: DATA DESCRIPTION
section.para: In each plot, we installed two replicate Decagon soil moisture and temperature probes (Model 5TM) to 5 cm depth. Decagon 5TM probes record soil moisture as volumetric water content (VWC; reported as % based on m3/m3) calculated using the Topp et al. (1980; Equation 1) from apparent dielectric permittivity (Æa) ranging from 1 in air to 80 in water (Decagon Devices 2010). The probes have a resolution of 0.08% VWC from 0-50% VWC and an accuracy of Â± 3% in typical mineral soils with solution electrical conductivity less than 10 dS/m and Â± 15% from 40-80% VWC. The temperature range is from -40 to 50 oC, with a resolution of 0.1 oC and an accuracy of 1 oC. Measurements were recorded hourly using a Decagon Em50 datalogger (14 extensive plots) or Campbell Scientific datalogger (6 intensive plots). We used linear regressions to data from nearby installations for periods that preceded and followed the missing data, to fill gaps in the data sets. Outliers were excluded before calculating the hourly mean of the two probes for each plot.

citation.title: Electromagnetic Determination of Soil Water Content: Measurement in Coaxial Transmission Lines

dataTable.entityDescription: Soil moisture and temperature along an elevation gradient. Volumetric water content is reported as percent, calculated as cubic meter of water per cubic meter of soil

section.title: NOTES ON DATA
section.para: Interested parties are free to use these data for informational purposes but they cannot be used in any publication without permission of the author. The data is physically located at the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, NY and was updated in March 2013.
